comments:
The course focuses on integrative aspects of physiological function of vertebrates.
Comparative, environmental and quantitative approaches are used. Major topics include
muscle, the cardiovascular system, respiration, renal function and the nervous system.
This course is concerned with basic principles governing the physiology of
vertebrates. Students found that in this course physiology came alive with all the
applications encountered in the course. Many students mainly relied on the textbook or
outside research to learn the material in this course. Students warn that the course is very
math based. In addition, they found the course to be disorganized.
Students thought professor Rome was funny. They describe him as friendly and
approachable. However, found his handouts to be very confusing and unhelpful. In
addition, his use of transparencies was found to be extremely unhelpful in
communicating the course material.
The prerequisites for this course include BIOL 102 or 121 of 124. This class is
recommended for students interested in medicine because the material of the course is
very relevant. Students said the course is very difficult. They found that exams did not
assess a student’s knowledge of the class material, but rather were experimental set-ups
that students were required to analyze. In addition, the grading for this course is very
difficult, and usually very little partial credit is awarded. There is also little help outside
lecture for the student.

The course focuses on integrative aspects of physiological function of vertebrates.
Comparative, environmental and quantitative approaches are used. Major topics include
muscle, the cardiovascular system, respiration, renal function and the nervous system.
Overall students felt that the concepts covered in the lecture were too simple.
Exams had more calculation based questions, which students felt they weren’t prepared
for. They wished that the lecture was filled with more sample questions that involved
calculations. However, some felt that the problem solving in class was “interesting and
useful.” Students thought that the handouts were difficult to understand and they found
that often, they had to teach themselves the material.
Students felt that overall there was a “disconnect” between professors and TAs,
which made it more difficult for students to get their questions answered. Some felt that
Dr. Ren wasted too much time by going off on tangents, which caused them to go too
slowly over the course material. Also, the majority felt that Dr. Ren’s accent also made it
difficult to understand what he said.
Students felt that this course was “challenging.” One student felt that the exams
did not reflect what material the students knew. This course is recommended for biology
majors or premedical students. The prerequisites for this course are BIOL 102, BIOL
121, or BIOL 124.

Vertebrate physiology focuses on integrative aspects of the physiological function
of vertebrates. Comparative, environmental, and quantitative approaches are used. Major
topics include muscles, the cardiovascular system, respiration, renal function, and the
nervous system.
Many students recommended this class and found it very interesting. However,
some students found the course description misleading, as it focused more on humans
than vertebrates in general. Many basic concepts were covered, and students generally
felt that the course requires a lot of memorization.
Students described Witmer as “genuinely interested in her students’ success.”
She was very responsive to students’ concerns, and they found her passion for the topic
“refreshing.”
This BIOL 215 section is an LPS section, so most of the students were post-grads.
